ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I appreciate gaining knowledge in R, especially seeing how it can be a useful skill that builds upon the types of statistical analyses we learned in the first part of the course.
I learned a good basis on statistical knowledge. I believe I can interpret information in scientific articles so much better.
Learned a bit of R, regressions, statistical significance, etc.
A lot of R coding that was not used in the class
Stats was a good intro to a lot fo topics and skills that would be very useful to me in the sciences. I think learning R was a really cool and useful experience.

I learned how to use R, which I found very interesting. I chose to take the Life Science section for the last five weeks of the course and really enjoyed analyzing data from biology experiments because it gave me the chance to apply some of the basic concepts taught in the first half of the course to a topic of interest to me.
I learned basic statistics and how it can be applied to life science research. I also learned the basics of R.
Introduction to statistics concepts and softwares (R and Minitab).
Understanding of R and basic statistical analysis
A solid understanding of R, flexible and comprehensive understanding of application and mechanics of statistical concepts
I learned how to determine if a variable is a statistically significant predictor of an effect, and the different methods to apply on figuring that out
Understanding of basic statistical concepts, using R and minitab, and practice with my first QR class at Yale in attending office hours and doing PSETs
I learned about the basics of statistics and then gained an understanding for how to provide an in-depth statistical analysis of life-science data.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Since this is a survey course, it felt like we were brushing over the topics sometimes rather than actually understanding the reasons behind the equations. This is expected since this wasn't a proof-based course. But it would be great to focus a bit more on the essential ideas behind the rules.

strength: the information is very approachable 
weakness: sometimes it does go by very fast and the life science section did not have as much support as I think we needed
The change in what we were learning between 100 and 101 felt very abrupt

I think the course is taught well in terms of the umbrella part of the course and then the more focused life sciences section. The material was taught very quickly however and sometimes it would have been helpful to spend a little more time on concepts.

strengths- good office hours, good feedback on HW
weaknesses- slow grading (didnt have 2 pset s graded before the final exam)

A bit of a jump when the course was split by subject in the second half. I don't feel that the course really benefitted from specializing in one topic, since the second half of the course was still general informations.

Both Professors had great lectures, although Professor Reuning-Scherer goes very fast (which he owns up to at the beginning of the course) and I found myself struggling to keep up some of the time. I like the weekly psets and think they are a good way to assess comprehension.

There was honestly too much material that was only briefly covered that left me very confused. The slides were also not helpful at all. The problem sets were not that difficult but it was hard to discern what answers were looked for. Overall, everything was very confusing in this class.

Strengths - online lectures and office hours
Weaknesses - feedback

Strengths: well organized, helpful tfs, good lecturer 

Weaknesses: Data camp

Strengths: JDRS is very clear, the slides were organized, and there were lots of office hours. 
the weakness was with Professor Jetz's section.. there was only one TF and there were not enough office hours. Professor Jetz was much less organized with the slides and material (there was a lot of talking but less info on the slides) which made it harder to review the information

Strengths: there are a TON of resources for this class, especially the first half (the recorded lectures are really helpful and there are so many office hours). JDRS is the best lecturer I've had at Yale. Exams and psets were all fair and well-spaced throughout the semester. 
Weaknesses/improvements: I thought the second half of the course (S&DS 101) moved too slow in the beginning and too fast at the end. It would have been nice to have an Ed Discussion board or equivalent for 101 too.

The first part of the course provided a broad overview of many statistics topics, but it was hard to contextualize them and understand their significance. I appreciate the exposure to many topics, but I am not sure how effective it is if you do not understand them, so I would recommend spending a little more time on the important topics and saving the minor ones for more advanced classes. On the other hand, the life sciences class was a deep dive into statistical analysis, and I enjoyed this format very much.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, managing data is a really useful skill regardless of the area. So regardless of the major, this is a great intro course that equips you with the skill set necessary to pursue further work in stats.
As long as it is relevant for their specific field of interest or major.

I would recommend intro stats to someone who has not had any background in the topic because it is important. However, the life science section seemed much harder than the other sections for not reason, so I would maybe choose another section if you have the option.
Not unless you are interested in R or need to take the class
I would recommend this course to anyone who things statistics would be a good background have for their major, interest or career.
Very accessible as an intro to stats.

This course was a good introduction to statistics. I'd never taken a stats course before and this was a great intro. This course does cover a lot of material and it's so great that all the exams are open note.

I would! I think that the most valuable portion of the course was the last five weeks in which I opted to focus on life science statistics methods and problems. I enjoyed learning R and thought that Professor Jetz was a brilliant lecturer and went at a pace that made the material fairly easy to digest and comprehend. I don't think I would recommend this course if not for that second, more focus component, as I already knew a good bit of the basic statistics information, but had never before experimented with R.
I think everything was too rushed and it was difficult to learn. I might recommend another introductory course.
Recommend for anyone who may want a foundation in statistical analysis.

Yes, I most definitely would. To any student that is interested in research in any disciplines of Science, the content taught in this course is extremely useful for conducting research, and the inculcation of a statistical framework is also important to understanding literature in the field.
Yes. Helpful to know.
Yes, i think its helpful for students who are interested in picking up data analysis skills outside of excel

I took this course because it was required for my major. due to the difficult and unclear nature of Professor Jetz's course, I would not recommend it, but I would definitely recommend JDRS, it was a somewhat mechanical course but I feel I gained a good foundational statistics knowledge
Yes-- it's fun, not too hard, and I learned practical skills that I hope to use in my science in the near future.
I would, it is helpful for most disciplines
